title: Mineworkers Kick Against Job Outsourcing
text:
8 September 2015 12:12 CET Mineworkers Kick Against Job Outsourcing By Daily Guide 
The union leaders with some dignitaries 
The Ghana Mineworkers' Union (GMWU) has expressed displeasure about the massive outsourcing of jobs in the mining sector. 
According to GMWU, employment in the mining industry was rapidly moving from the long and permanent status to precarious fixed term contracts, which does not auger well for stakeholders. 
Kwarko Mensah Gyakari, National Chairperson of GMWU, who was speaking at the 11th Quadrennial Delegates Conference of the Union recently held in Tarkwa, Western Region, called for urgent steps to tackle the massive outsourcing of jobs in the mining sector. 
The situation is getting worst, as some labour brokers, whose only duty is to facilitate employment have turned themselves into employers and are abusing workers' rights, he said. 
'We want to caution such organizations to end the practice now or face the wrath of the union,' Mr Gyakari said. 
Kofi Asamoah, TUC Secretary-General, in his remarks, said it was unfortunate that mining companies were resisting attempts by government to impose windfall tax due to the stability clauses in the mining agreements. 
He observed that owing to the end of the mining boom, the companies had closed down the mines that have rendered thousands of workers jobless. 
'The actions of the mining companies indicate in the strongest possible terms their unpreparedness to bear any costs on our behalf,' Mr Asamoah added. 
In view of these developments, it is about time serious discussions about the 'indigenization' of the mines begin, he said. 
ICU Support Solomon Kotei, General Secretary of Industrial and Commercial Workers Union (ICU), said his outfit would support the Ghana Mineworkers' Union in its efforts to ensure equity in remuneration in the mining sector without disparities and race discrimination. 
He said the posture of management of some mining companies was inimical to the long-standing and revered principle of 'equal pay for equal work' enshrined in international labour conventions which Ghana has subscribed to. 
By Cephas Larbi
